metadata.case_name: D.M. Manasvi v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: The assessee is an individual. Matter relates to assessment years 1959-60, 1960-61, 1961-62 and 1962-63.
During relevant years, assessee derived income from several sources.
Assessment for 1959-60 made under section 23(3) of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.
Income Tax Officer (ITO) found income from business in name of M/s. Kohinoor Grain Mills Sales Depot (Kohinoor Mills) not included in return for 1959-60; assessee showed no connection or interest.
For subsequent three years (1960-61 to 1962-63), assessee disclosed 20% as his share of profits from Kohinoor Mills.
ITO opined Kohinoor Mills was not genuine partnership but sole proprietorship concern of assessee; whole income belonged to assessee.
Assessments for first two years (1959-60, 1960-61) already completed before ITO got information; ITO reopened them.
Income from Kohinoor Mills included in assessee's income for all four years.
ITO's order upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC) and Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (Tribunal).
Non-disclosure of Kohinoor Mills profits considered deliberate concealment by ITO; initiated penalty proceedings under s.271 for four years.
Minimum penalty exceeded Rs.1000; cases referred under s.274(2) to Inspecting Assistant Commissioner (IAC).
IAC heard assessee; concluded concealment and inaccurate particulars for all four years; levied penalties: Rs.21,062 (1959-60), Rs.1,14,477 (1960-61), Rs.2,02,584 (1961-62), Rs.1,02,731 (1962-63).

Tribunal in penalty appeal: Rejected invalid initiation; held proceedings commenced via directions in assessment order for notice u/s 271(1)(c); rejected no evidence of ownership/concealment; reduced quantum.
On assessee's application, two questions referred u/s 256(1) to Gujarat High Court.
High Court answered both questions in affirmative, in favour of department; for 1961-62, held penalty proceedings invalid.
In assessment orders, ITO held Kohinoor Mills wrongly shown as partnership; other partners name-lenders; proprietary concern of assessee; ordered notice for penalty u/s 271(1)(c).

Tribunal earlier refused registration to Kohinoor Mills as firm; found Ramanbhai Thakorlal, Gopaldas, Kirit not real partners (dummies, minors grandchildren); business controlled by D.M. Manasvi; profits extracted by him; no firm existed.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, proceedings for imposition of penalty were properly commenced in the course of any proceedings under the Act as required by s.271 for assessment years 1959-60 to 1962-63?

Whether on the facts and circumstances, there was any material or evidence before the Tribunal to hold that assessee deliberately concealed particulars of income or furnished inaccurate particulars u/s 271(1)(c) for 1959-60 to 1962-63?

petitioner_arguments.text: No proper initiation of penalty proceedings; no requisite satisfaction of ITO shown.
No material or evidence before Tribunal for deliberate concealment or inaccurate particulars.
Penalty proceedings initiated by IAC on reference u/s 274(2), not by ITO.
ITO should have issued prior notice and held preliminary enquiry before satisfaction and notice.

respondent_arguments.text: Countered assessee's submissions on initiation and material for concealment; submissions without merit.

court_reasoning.text: Satisfaction of ITO during assessment proceedings (held Kohinoor proprietary concern, ordered penalty notice) suffices for initiation u/s 271(1)(c), even if notice issued later; not essential notice during assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Satisfaction precedes notice; complies if during proceedings under Act.

court_reasoning.text: No notice produced; cannot assume lack of satisfaction mention.
Reference to IAC u/s 274(2) does not mean no initiation by ITO; ITO initiates, then refers if penalty > Rs.1000.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Satisfaction of ITO basis for proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: No need for prior notice/preliminary enquiry before satisfaction/notice; would duplicate procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prima facie satisfaction before hearing assessee.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal had material: business controlled by assessee; no real firm; dummies; profits his; deliberate device to conceal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Positive material, not mere falsity of explanation.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Anwar Ali: here positive findings of device, not mere false explanation.

holdings.text: Penalty proceedings properly commenced if ITO satisfied during proceedings under Act, even if notice later.
Material before Tribunal suffices for deliberate concealment u/s 271(1)(c).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. S.V. Angidi Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Satisfaction during proceedings under Act required for penalty; no need to commence before completion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. M/s. Mahaliram Ramjidas
precedents_cited.relevance: No prior notice/enquiry needed before initiating proceedings; avoids duplication.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal v. Anwar Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Penalty needs entirety pointing to concealment; mere false explanation insufficient; here positive material.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Khoday Eswarsa and Sons
precedents_cited.relevance: Penalty not solely on original assessment reasons; here based on registration refusal appeal.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Penalty for concealment; procedure on reference if >Rs.1000; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed assessee's appeals by special leave against Gujarat High Court judgment answering questions in favour of department; upheld validity of penalty proceedings initiation and sufficiency of material for concealment (noting 1961-62 invalidity not in issue).

key_quotes.text: "Satisfaction in the very nature of things precedes the issue of notice and it would not be correct to equate the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer... with the actual issue of notice."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies timing of satisfaction vs notice for penalty initiation.

key_quotes.text: "The power to impose penalty... depends upon the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer in the course of proceedings under the Act... Satisfaction before conclusion of the proceeding under the Act, and not the issue of a notice..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Angidi Chettiar on condition for jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "There is no doubt left in our minds that... the business belonged to Shri D.M. Manasvi."
key_quotes.speaker: tribunal
key_quotes.significance: Tribunal finding on proprietorship justifying concealment.
